title: Bourne End Academy
content:
{{Infobox UK school | name = Bourne End Academy | image = File:Bourne End Academy Small Logo.jpg | size = 200px | latitude = 51.58075 | longitude = -0.70549 | dms = dms | motto = Believe, Engage, Aspire | motto_pl = | established = | approx = | closed = | c_approx = | type = [[Academy (English school)|Academy]]; [[Secondary modern]] | religion = | president = | head_label = Headteacher | head = Andrea Jacobson (2013-present) || chair_label = Directors | chair = Charlotte Mattingley
Clayton Bannon
Michael Rooke
Corrine Gill{{cite web|author1=Andrea Jacobson|title=Academy Notification|url=http://www.wyevalley.bucks.sch.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/ACADEMY-NOTIFICATION-APRIL-2014.pdf|publisher=The Wye Valley School|accessdate=21 December 2014|date=14 January 2014}} | Assistant Headteacher_label = Assistant Headteacher | street = New Road | city = [[Bourne End, Buckinghamshire|Bourne End]] | county = [[Buckinghamshire]] | country = [[England]] | postcode = SL8 5BW | LEA = [[Buckinghamshire County Council|Buckinghamshire]] | ofsted = yes | urn = 110508 | staff = | enrollment = 789 | gender = Mixed | lower_age = 11 | upper_age = 18 | houses = | colours = [[Burgundy (color)|Burgundy]] and [[Black]] {{color box|Red}}{{color box|Black}} | publication = | free_label_2 = | free_2 = | free_label_3 = | free_3 = | website = http://www.bea.bucks.sch.uk/ | website_name = www.bea.bucks.sch.uk |int_head = Mrs Andrea Jacobsen|int_head_label = Headteacher}} '''Bourne End Academy''', previously 'The Wye Valley School', is a co-educational [[Secondary education#England, Wales and Northern Ireland|secondary school]] in [[Bourne End, Buckinghamshire]], England. It is a [[secondary school]], which takes pupils from the age of 11 to 18. The school is much smaller than an average secondary school, with just under 800 pupils attending every year. {{cite web | last= | first= | authorlink= | coauthors= | title=Schools Directory | work= | publisher=Buckinghamshire County Council | date= | url=http://apps.buckscc.gov.uk/eforms/schools/schoolDetails.aspx?DFEE=4094 | format= | doi= | accessdate=2006-08-03}} In September 1998 the school was awarded [[specialist school]] status as a [[Sports College]] and furthermore, in 2012, the school was awarded the status of a specialist Science College, by the [[Department for Education and Skills (United Kingdom)|Department for Education and Skills (DfES)]].{{cite web | last= | first= | authorlink= | coauthors= | title=Specialist Schools Home | work= | publisher=DfES | date=July 2006 | url=http://www.standards.dfes.gov.uk/specialistschools/ | format= | doi= | accessdate=2006-07-28}} Bourne End Academy is also one of only a number of schools in the area to possess a special department for students on the [[Autistic spectrum]], named as the A.R.P. (Additional Resources Provision) Department. The academy offers a range of different opportunities to all pupils, including extra curricular clubs. In 2012 Wye Valley achieved 47% A*-C grades (including English and Mathematics) at GCSE with the results below national level placing it in the [[quantile|4th quantile]] in comparison to other schools.{{cite web | last= | first= | authorlink= | coauthors= | title=Ofsted School Data Dashboard for The Wye Valley School | work= | publisher=Ofsted | year=2012 | url=http://dashboard.ofsted.gov.uk/dash.php?urn=110508 | format= | doi= | accessdate=2013-06-05}} [[File:The Wye Valley School.jpg|thumbnail|The school's main entrance, situated on New Road.]] The school was put in to a state of '[[Special measures|Special Measures]]' after both the school, and its management, were classified as 'Inadequate' by [[Ofsted]] in January 2013. After the report, the school's governing body was disbanded, and an Interim Executive Board (IEB) was imposed, which as of March 2014, is still in place. From its beginning, the headteacher of the school was Ms Linda Melton. After 30 years of service, Melton left in 2010 and was replaced by Mr Jonathon Oliver. Oliver announced his resignation from the school in July 2013 after a two-month leave with Sharon Cromie taking role of Executive Headteacher. Cromie has recently passed the job on to Andrea Jacobsen, who was appointment full-time headteacher in March 2014. An Ofsted report published on 2 April noted the school's relevant improvements since being placed in special measures. The school moved out of this rating after changing to an academy. ==A-Levels== Bourne End Academy currently has a 6th form for students studying [[A Level|AS]] Levels and [[A Level|A2]] Levels. *[[Mathematics]] *[[English Literature]] *[[Biology]] *[[Chemistry]] *[[History]] *[[Geography]] *[[Philosophy of religion]] *[[Ethics]] and [[Applied ethics]] *[[Business Studies]] *[[Media Studies]] *[[Information and communication technologies|ICT]] *[[Sport]] *[[Dance]] *[[Art]] *[[Music Technology|Music Performance and Technology]] (BTEC) *[[Photography]] *[[Health and Social Care]] (BTEC) *[[Sport]] (BTEC) *[[Football Coaching]] - Also open to partnership students from other schools *[[Sociology]] - Also open to partnership students from other schools *[[Psychology]] - Also open to partnership students from other schools *[[Leisure Studies]] Bourne End Academy is also part of a partnership of four schools (that teach three of the twelve 'partnership courses' at their schools) to allow students at their school to additionally study [[Physics]], [[Ancient History]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Economics]], [[Textiles]], [[Product Design]] and [[Law]] ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.education.gov.uk/cgi-bin/schools/performance/school.pl?urn=110508 Department for Education Performance Tables 2011] {{Schools in Buckinghamshire}} [[Category:Secondary schools in Buckinghamshire]] [[Category:Academies in Buckinghamshire]]

title: User:Softlavender/draft
content:
{{Infobox person
| name        = <!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name -->
| image       = Chobani President and CEO Ulukaya Delivers Remarks (7256160358).jpg <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] -->
| alt         = 
| caption     = Ulukaya receiving the National Entrepreneurial Success Award of 2012 from the [[Small Business Administration|SBA]]
| birth_name  = 
| birth_date  = {{Birth year and age|1972}} <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Birth-date and age|Month DD, YYYY}} -->
| birth_place = [[Erzincan Province|Erzincan,Turkey]] | death_date  = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) -->
| death_place = 
| nationality = [[Turkey|Turkish]]-[[United States|American]]
| other_names = 
| occupation  = Entrepreneur, businessman
| known_for   = Founder and owner of [[Chobani]]
}}

'''Hamdi Ulukaya''' (born 1972) is a [[Turkey|Turkish]]-[[United States|American]] entrepreneur and businessman of [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] descent. He is the founder and CEO of [[Chobani]], the number one–selling [[strained yogurt|Greek yogurt]] brand in the U.S. 

Originating from a dairy-farming family in a small village in Turkey, Ulukaya came to the U.S. in 1994 to study English and took a few business courses as well. He started a modest feta-cheese factory in 2002 on the advice of his father, but his real success came from taking a major risk: purchasing a large defunct yogurt factory in upstate New York in 2005. With no prior experience in the yogurt business, he created a yogurt empire, Chobani, that went from zero to over $1 billion in annual sales in less than five years, becoming the leading yogurt brand in the U.S. by 2011.<ref name=winograd>Winograd, David. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/18/chobani-ceo-hamdi-ulukaya_n_3459615.html "Chobani CEO Hamdi Ulukaya: Startups Are 'Cool' But Let's Focus On People Who 'Make Things'"]. ''[[Huffington Post]]''. June 18, 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/20/idUS119598+20-Apr-2011+PRN20110420 "Chobani Takes Top Spot as America's #1 Selling Yogurt Brand"]. ''[[Reuters]]''. April 20, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/video/chobani-ceo-we-have-to-go-back-to-making-things-LPbY3AVvR~6nYGZWAsxr9g.html "Chobani Yogurt CEO: I Had No Business Experience"]. ''[[Bloomberg TV]]''. February 12, 2014.</ref> The popularity of his Greek-style yogurt also sparked the rise in Greek yogurt's market share in the U.S. from less than 1% in 2007 to more than 50% in 2013.<ref name=winograd /> [[Ernst & Young]] named Ulukaya the World Entrepreneur of the Year in 2013.<ref name=ey2013>[http://www.ey.com/GL/en/Newsroom/News-releases/News_Hamdi-Ulukaya-of-Chobani-named-Ernst---Young-World-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year-2013 "Hamdi Ulukaya of Chobani named EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year 2013"]. [[Ernst & Young]]. June 9, 2013.</ref> The success of his yogurt empire made Ulukaya a billionaire, and according to ''[[Forbes]]'', his net worth as of 2014 is $1.4 billion.<ref name=billionaires>[http://www.forbes.com/profile/hamdi-ulukaya/ Hamdi Ulukaya]. Profile on ''[[Forbes]]''{{'}}s Billionaires.</ref>

==Early life, education, and early career==
Hamdi Ulukaya was born in 1972 to a [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] family in [[Turkey]].  His family owned and operated a sheep, goat, and dairy farm near the [[Euphrates River]] in [[İliç|Ilic]], [[Erzincan Province]], making cheese and yogurt.<ref name=gross>Gross, Daniel. [http://mag.newsweek.com/2013/06/12/the-turkish-shepherd-behind-chobani.html "It's All Greek to Him: Chobani's Unlikely Success Story"]. ''[[Newsweek]]''. June 12, 2013.</ref><ref name=weisul>Weisul, Kimberly. [http://www.inc.com/kimberly-weisul/chobanis-hamdi-ulukaya-dairy-boy-made-good.html "How Turkish 'Dairy Boy' Hamdi Ulukaya Started $600 Million Chobani"]. ''[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]'' October 17, 2012.</ref><ref name=mead>Mead, Rebecca. [http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/11/04/just-add-sugar "Just Add Sugar: How an immigrant from Turkey turned Greek yogurt into an American snack food"]. ''[[The New Yorker]]''. November 4, 2013.</ref> The family often led a seasonally semi-nomadic existence tending and herding their flocks, and Ulukaya is uncertain of his exact birth date because he was born during one of the family's mountain treks.<ref name=mead />

After studying political science at [[Ankara University]], in 1994 he moved to the United States to study English at [[Adelphi University]] on [[Long Island]], [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref name=colgate>[http://web.archive.org/web/20140124164749/http://www.colgate.edu/offices-and-services/commencement/speakers "Honorary Degree Recipients: Hamdi Ulukaya, Doctor of Humane Letters"]. [[Colgate University]], 2013. ''Colgate.edu''.</ref> In 1997 he moved [[upstate New York|upstate]] and transferred to the [[University at Albany, State University of New York]] where he enrolled in a few business courses.<ref name=colgate /><ref name=prasso>Prasso, Sheridan. [http://money.cnn.com/2011/11/29/smallbusiness/chobani_yogurt_hamdi_ulukaya.fortune/ "Chobani: The unlikely king of yogurt"]. ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]''. December 12, 2011.</ref> 

He ended up taking a job on an upstate farm, and when his father visited he convinced Hamdi to import the family's [[feta cheese]] from Turkey after tasting the inferior cheese available locally. When the imported cheese proved popular, Hamdi opened a small wholesale feta cheese plant of his own, called Euphrates, in [[Johnstown, New York]] in 2002.<ref name=mead /><ref name=ft>Fifield, Anna. [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/fe252dc2-a07b-11e2-a6e1-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2kiqtoyLa "Founder follows his gut instincts"]. ''[[Financial Times]]''. April 9, 2013.</ref><ref name=prasso /> The venture was modestly successful but by the two-year mark it had just barely broken even;<ref name=ulukaya /> Ulukaya later recalled, "It was two years of the most challenging days of my life."<ref name=prasso />

==Chobani==
===Inception and development===
In the spring of 2005, Ulukaya noticed a piece of junk mail advertising a fully equipped yogurt factory for sale in [[South Edmeston, New York]], 65 miles west of his feta cheese factory.<ref name=ulukaya /> The 84-year-old factory had been closed by [[Kraft Foods]].<ref name=ulukaya/><ref name=gruley>Gruley, Bryan. [http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-01-31/at-chobani-the-turkish-king-of-greek-yogurt "At Chobani, the Turkish King of Greek Yogurt"]. ''[[BusinessWeek]]''. January 31, 2013.</ref> Although he initially threw the flier away,<ref name=gruley /> Ulukaya toured the plant the following day and decided to buy it, against the advice of his attorney and business advisor.<ref name=ft /> Ulukaya financed the purchase within five months with a loan from the [[Small Business Administration]] plus local business-incentive grants.<ref name=mead /><ref name=ft /><ref name=needleman>Needleman, Sarah E. [http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303379204577476974123310582 "Old Factory, Snap Decision Spawn Greek-Yogurt Craze"]. ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''. June 20, 2012.</ref> He initially named his new company Agro Farma, and hired a handful of the former Kraft employees.<ref name=prasso /><ref name=needleman /> As a first task they painted and repaired the neglected factory. 

Ulukaya felt that American-style yogurt was too sugary, watery, and artificial, and much preferred the thick, [[strained yogurt]] he grew up enjoying on a daily basis in Turkey.<ref name=ulukaya>Ulukaya, Hamdi. [http://www.l4lbs.org/startuptip.PDF "Chobani’s Founder on Growing a Start-Up Without Outside Investors"]. ''[[Harvard Business Review]]''. October 2013.</ref> His aim was to create a quality, tasty, natural, and affordable strained or "Greek" yogurt for the U.S. market. He brought over a yogurt master from Turkey, Mustafa Dogan, with whom he spent nearly two years developing and perfecting his own yogurt recipe.<ref name=ft /> Using different bacterial cultures at differing temperatures and durations, they tested hundreds of recipes to come up with a yogurt with the desired taste, texture, and natural shelf life.<ref name=gruley /> 

Strained, or "Greek" yogurt as it is called in the U.S., is much thicker, creamier, and tangier, and more protein-rich, because the [[whey]] is strained out. To manufacture strained yogurt, Ulukaya needed a million-dollar commercial machine called a yogurt separator, which the American-style Kraft factory did not have. He found a used one in Wisconsin and negotiated to buy it for $50,000. On his trip to pick up the separator, the name "Chobani"  – a variation on ''çoban'', the Turkish word for shepherd – popped into his head.<ref name=mead /><ref name=gruley />

Ulukaya made [[Chobani]] yogurt without preservat­ives, artificial flavors, artificial colors, or gelatin, and used only milk from cows not treated with [[Bovine somatotropin|growth hormones]].<ref name=ft /><ref name=mead /><ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/video/69182574-agro-farma-s-ulukaya-interview-about-chobani-yogurt.html "Agro-Farma's Ulukaya Interview About Chobani Yogurt"]. ''[[Bloomberg TV]]''. April 29, 2011.</ref> Since he couldn't afford advertising, he invested time and money on the product's packaging, using a distinctive new bowl-style shape to differentiate the brand,<ref name=ft /><ref name=ulukaya /> and ensuring its design and bright coloring stood out from other yogurts.<ref name=gruley /> The first line-up of Chobani flavors included plain, vanilla, strawberry, peach, and blueberry.<ref name=mead />

===Launch===
Ulukaya wanted Chobani to be easily affordable. Rather than marketing to small specialty stores, he aimed the yogurt at the regular dairy sections of mainstream grocery stores and national chains, thus aiding the product's rapid growth and adoption by consumers.<ref name=prasso /><ref name=ulukaya /><ref name=durisin>Durisin, Megan.[http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/business/companies/130503/chobani-yogurt-startup-success-ceo-hamdi-ulukaya "Chobani CEO: Our success has nothing to do with yogurt"]. ''[[Business Insider]]''. May 3, 2013.</ref> 

In October 2007, he shipped his first order of Chobani, a few hundred cases, to a grocer on Long Island. The store repeated the order the following week.<ref name=gross /><ref name=gruley /> 

Ulukaya's early business approach included strategies the big companies did not use. Rather than pay stores a [[slotting fee]], which his start-up company could not afford, he paid stores in yogurt rather than in cash to stock his wares, and also negotiated to pay off the slotting fees over time as the yogurt sold.<ref name=walden>Walden, Mark. [http://news.colgate.edu/2013/04/chobani-creator-tells-his-story-at-entrepreneur-weekend.html "Hamdi Ulukaya tells his story at Entrepreneur Weekend"]. [[Colgate University|Colgate University – ''Colgate News'']]. ''Colgate.edu''. April 8, 2013.</ref><ref name=ulukaya /> He also implemented in-store samples so customers could taste the product and purchase it immediately.<ref>Pride, William; Hughes, Robert; Kapoor, Jack. [http://books.google.com/books?id=5ZSxykh6Hx0C&pg=PA395 ''Business'']. Cengage Learning, 2013. p. 395.</ref> Lacking the budget for traditional marketing, after hearing customers phoning in saying they loved Chobani, Ulukaya had his small team reach out to bloggers, Facebook, and Twitter to have constant and direct communication with consumers.<ref name=walters /> In 2010 he also created a sampling truck, the  CHOmobile, which handed out free cups of Chobani yogurt at festivals, parades, and other family-friendly events all over the U.S.<ref name=needleman /><ref name=psfk>[http://www.psfk.com/2013/04/hamdi-ulukaya-psfk-2013.html "Chobani Founder: Why Quality & Community Are they Keys To Brand Success"]. ''PSFK.com''. April 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/news/features/2013/mar13/03-19chobani.aspx "Chobani Increases Its Appetite for Business Growth With Microsoft Technologies"]. ''Microsoft News Center''. March 19, 2013.</ref> In its first year, the sample truck gave away 150,000 full-size containers of Chobani.<ref name=walters>Walters, Kath. [http://leadingcompany.smartcompany.com.au/execution/cmi-industrial-door-closes-chobani-australia-opens/20120503916 "CMI Industrial door closes, Chobani Australia opens"]. ''[[Leading Company]]''. May 3, 2012.</ref>

In 2009, the chain stores [[Stop & Shop]] and [[ShopRite (United States)|ShopRite]] began carrying Chobani,<ref name=tuder>Tuder, Stephanie. [http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/lifestyle/2014/01/charting-greek-yogurts-amazing-rise/ "Charting Greek Yogurt’s Amazing Rise"]. ''[[ABC News]]''. January 21, 2014.</ref> and by the middle of 2009, Chobani was selling 200,000 cases a week.<ref name=gruley /> Later that same year, a major breakthrough came when the [[warehouse club]] stores [[BJ's Wholesale Club]] and [[Costco]] began carrying the brand.<ref name=durisin /><ref name=prasso />  

===Expansion===
After BJ's and Costco began carrying Chobani in 2009, the company doubled it sales every year through 2013.<ref name=grenoble>Grenoble, Ryan. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/14/hamdi-ulukaya-chobani-billionaire_n_1884598.html "Hamdi Ulukaya, Chobani Yogurt Founder, One Of The World's Newest Billionaires"]. ''[[Huffington Post]]''. September 14, 2012.</ref> With an eye on Australian and Asian markets, in 2011 Ulukaya acquired [[Melbourne]] dairy producer Bead Foods, and began manufacturing and selling Chobani in [[Australia]].<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/small-business/entrepreneur/wild-ride-the-steve-jobs-of-yoghurt-shares-his-secrets-20120224-1ts8t.html "Wild ride: the 'Steve Jobs of yoghurt' shares his secrets"]. ''[[The Age]]''. February 27, 2012.</ref><ref name=walters /> In mid 2012, he initiated a $88.5 million expansion for the company, acquiring 100 acres next to its upstate New York facility and building an 80,000-square-foot addition. The expansion was partially funded by $1.5 million in New York State grants.<ref>Nearing, Brian. [http://www.timesunion.com/business/article/Chobani-Yogurt-receives-1-5M-grant-from-state-3717597.php "Chobani Yogurt receives $1.5M grant from state"]. ''[[Times Union (Albany)|Times-Union]]''. July 18, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.bizjournals.com/albany/news/2012/07/18/chobani-expansion-project-will-benefit.html "Chobani expansion project will benefit from $1.5 million in state grants"]. ''[[American City Business Journals|Albany Business Review]]''. July 18, 2012.</ref> 

Since strained or Greek yogurt uses three times the amount of milk per cup that unstrained yogurt does, to keep up with Chobani's ever-increasing market, and demands for higher and higher quantities of milk, in December 2012 the company opened the world's largest yogurt factory in [[Twin Falls, Idaho]], a $450 million investment.<ref>Strom, Stephanie. [http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/17/business/chobani-to-open-huge-yogurt-factory-in-idaho.html "U.S. Hunger for Yogurt Leads to Gigantic Factory"]. ''[[New York Times]]''. December 16, 2012.</ref> In 2012 Chobani had more than $1 billion in annual sales,<ref name=foundations /><ref>[http://www.foodprocessing.com/industrynews/2013/chobani-hires-new-executives/ "Chobani Hires Two Top Executives"]. ''FoodProcessing.com''. July 12, 2013.</ref> and in 2012 it became the world's leading yogurt brand.<ref name=winograd /> By dint of his success, Ulukaya joined the world's billionaires in the early 2010s; his net worth as of 2014 is $1.4 billion.<ref name=billionaires />

Ulukaya began adding new product lines to his brand in 2010, beginning with Chobani Champions, a Greek yogurt designed for children. In 2013 he added the Chobani Bite, a small indulgent yogurt with flavors including chocolate; Chobani Flip, yogurt with a separate section of toppings; and Chobani Simply 100, marketed as the first and only 100-calorie Greek yogurt made with only natural ingredients.<ref>[http://www.chobani.com/core/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Chobani_Press_Kit.pdf Chobani Timeline]. ''Chobani.com''. April 2013.</ref> In 2014 he launched Chobani Oats, a blend of Greek yogurt, steel-cut oats and fruit; Seasonal varieties, including watermelon and pink grapefruit; Chobani Indulgent, a healthy dessert yogurt; and a 4%-fat plain Greek yogurt marketed as particularly good for cooking and baking.<ref>Watson, Elaine. [http://www.foodnavigator-usa.com/Manufacturers/Chobani-takes-on-oatmeal-ice-cream-and-snacks-with-new-summer-launches "Chobani takes on oatmeal, ice cream and snacks with new summer launches"]. ''Food Navigator USA''. April 18, 2004.</ref> 

In 2012, he opened Chobani SoHo, a retail yogurt [[cafe]] in Manhattan's trendy [[SoHo]] district.<ref name=mead /> The cafe offers various exotic and gourmet dishes using flavors of fresh Chobani yogurt and gourmet toppings, as well as sandwiches, soups, and coffee.<ref>Zimmer, Erin. [http://newyork.seriouseats.com/2012/07/first-look-chobani-soho-greek-yogurt-bar.html "First Look: Chobani Soho"]. ''[[Serious Eats]]''. July 31, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.chobani.com/pdf/Menu.pdf Chobani SoHo – Menu]. ''Chobani.com''.</ref><ref>[http://www.chobani.com/culture/chobani-soho Chobani SoHo]. ''Chobani.com''.</ref>

Following the success of its product in Australia, in 2014 Chobani expanded its distribution to Asia and Latin America, beginning with [[Singapore]], [[Malaysia]], and [[Panama]]. The company announced plans for the [[Caribbean]] as well.<ref>Cazentre, Don. [http://www.syracuse.com/food/index.ssf/2014/04/chobani_goes_global_cny-based_yogurt_company_to_sell_in_asia_latin_america.html "Chobani goes global: CNY-based yogurt company to sell in Asia, Latin America"]. ''[[The Post-Standard]]''. April 16, 2014.</ref> In April 2014, Chobani reached a deal with private-equity firm [[TPG]] for a $750-million investment, which will fund the company's expansion and the launch of its newest line of products.<ref>Spector, Mike and Annie Gasparro. [http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304788404579520001311766952 "Chobani Reaches Deal for $750 Million Investment From TPG"]. ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''. April 23, 2014.</ref>

==Influence and advisorships==
Ulukaya has been noted both for his extraordinary entrepreneurial success and also his commitment to making affordable, delicious, and nutritious foods using only natural ingredients.<ref>Dieken, Connie. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/connie-dieken/the-top-influencers-alive_b_1161344.html "The Top Influencers Alive: 10 Breakout Influencers of 2011"]. ''[[Huffington Post]]''. December 26, 2011.</ref> In addition to receiving many entrepreneurship awards, in April 2014 he was named by President [[Barack Obama]] as an inaugural member of the Presidential Ambassadors for Global Entrepreurship (PAGE) initiative – 11 selected business leaders who will champion and encourage entrepreneurship in the U.S. and abroad.<ref name=page /><ref name=wapo>Harrison, J.D. [http://www.washingtonpost.com/business/on-small-business/meet-obamas-new-ambassadors-for-entrepreneurship/2014/04/07/8cd6457c-be91-11e3-b574-f8748871856a_story.html "Meet Obama’s new ambassadors for entrepreneurship"]. ''[[Washington Post]]''. April 8, 2014.</ref><ref name=sabah /> Also in  2014, the [[Culinary Institute of America]] honored him with its Leadership Award (Augie Award) in the Health and Wellness category.<ref name=cia />

Ulukaya is a member of the Upstate Regional Advisory Board of the [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York]],<ref>[http://www.newyorkfed.org/aboutthefed/ag_upstateny_regional.html Upstate New York Regional Advisory Board]. [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York]].</ref><ref>[http://www.newyorkfed.org/aboutthefed/annual/annual13/annual.pdf 2013 Annual Report]. [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York]].</ref> and he is a Vice Chair of the corporate fund board of the [[Kennedy Center|Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts]].<ref>[http://www.kennedy-center.org/support/corporate/corpboard.html Corporate Support: The 2014 Corporate Fund Board]. [[The Kennedy Center]].</ref> He is also on the board of the Pathfinder Village (Community for Down syndrome) Foundation in Edmeston, New York.<ref>[http://pathfindervillage.org/about-us/our-board/ Pathfinder Village Foundation Board]. ''PathfinderVillage.org''.</ref> He has delivered commencement addresses at institutions  including the [[Culinary Institute of America]],<ref>[http://www.ciachef.edu/grad-speaker-hamdi-ulukaya/ "Chobani Founder Delivers Commencement Address at CIA"]. [[Culinary Institute of America]]. May 29, 2013.</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mhg7kCUycsY "CIA Bachelor's Graduation Speaker: Hamdi Ulukaya"] (video). [[Culinary Institute of America]]. May 29, 2013.</ref> the [[Sage Colleges]],<ref>[https://mediasite.itops.rpi.edu/Mediasite5/Play/8e4d4cd4fef04d1f967da57e1ff460721d?catalog=c2ae3959-9eab-4635-93d3-8ffdec68f249 "The Sage Colleges 2013 Commencement Ceremony"]. [[Sage Colleges]].</ref> and the [[University at Albany]] in New York,<ref name=viccaro>Viccaro, Haley. [http://dailygazette.com/news/2014/may/19/0519ualbany/?free "2,116 receive degrees at the University at Albany"]. ''[[Daily Gazette]]''. May 19, 2014.</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rHYABnK4Oho "Chobani founder Hamdi Ulukaya's UAlbany Commencement Address"] (video). [[University at Albany]].</ref> and has he received [[honorary doctorate]] degrees from [[Colgate University]],<ref name=colgate /> the Sage Colleges,<ref name=sagephd /> and the University at Albany.<ref name=commencement>[http://www.albany.edu/commencement/honorary_degree_recipient.php "Noted Upstate New York Entrepreneurs to Deliver UAlbany Commencement Addresses, May 17 and 18"]. [[University at Albany]]. April 17, 2014.</ref><ref name=viccaro />

From its inception Ulukaya has given 10% of his company's net profits to charitable causes, and to individuals and organizations working towards positive long-lasting change.<ref>Craig, Victoria. [http://www.foxbusiness.com/business-leaders/2014/02/18/chobani-founder-american-dream-happened-to-me/ "Chobani Founder: The American Dream Happened to Me"]. ''[[FOX Business]]''. February 18, 2014.</ref><ref name=selected /> In 2010 he established the company's charitable arm, the Chobani Shepherd's Gift Foundation, now called the Chobani Foundation, to manage this philanthropy.<ref name=malone /><ref>[http://www.dandb.com/businessdirectory/chobanishepherdsgiftfoundationinc-norwich-ny-28808979.html Chobani Shepherd's Gift Foundation, Inc.]. ''[[Dun & Bradstreet]]''.</ref><ref name=selected>[http://www.sba.gov/offices/district/ny/syracuse/success-stories/chobani-selected-sbas-2012-national-entrepreneurial-success-year "Chobani Selected as SBA’s 2012 National Entrepreneurial Success of the Year"]. [[Small Business Administration]]. May 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.chobani.com/foundation Chobani Foundation]. ''Chobani.com''.</ref> Donations have included major grants to support famine relief efforts in [[Somalia]],<ref name=malone>Malone, Chris and Susan T. Fiske. [http://books.google.com/books?id=wfbUAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA83 ''The Human Brand: How We Relate to People, Products, and Companies'']. John Wiley & Sons, 2013. p. 83.</ref> and to underwrite the New York City Pianos project launched by [[Sing For Hope|Sing for Hope]].<ref>Cordon-Bouzan, Carolina. [http://www.dclifemagazine.com/health--body/philanthropic-foodies/ "Philanthropic Foodies"]. ''DC Life Magazine''. August 5, 2013.</ref><ref>[http://online.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20130530-911926.html "Third Annual Sing for Hope Pianos Begins This Weekend in New York City"]. ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''. May 30, 2013.</ref>

==Personal life==
Ulukaya lives in [[New Berlin (village), New York|New Berlin, New York]], not far from Chobani's South Edmeston factory and headquarters.<ref>[http://www.ey.com/US/en/Services/Strategic-Growth-Markets/Strategic-Growth-Forum-Agenda-EVTD-USDD-98SMD9 "Hamdi Ulukaya, Founder and CEO, Chobani, Inc. and EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year 2013 Award winner, interviewed by Mark A. Weinberger, EY Global Chairman & CEO"]. [[Ernst & Young]]. 2013.</ref> He was briefly married in the late 1990s to Ayse Giray.<ref>Hornbeck, Eric. [http://www.law360.com/articles/389243/judge-pauses-chobani-founder-s-ex-wife-s-530m-suit "Judge Pauses Chobani Founder's Ex-Wife's $530M Suit"]. ''[[Law360]]''. October 24, 2012.</ref> 

Ulukaya has additional offices in Manhattan and [[Twin Falls, Idaho]].<ref>Geller, Martinne. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/18/chobani-hamdi-ulukaya_n_2319095.html "Chobani Chief Executive Hamdi Ulukaya Mulls The Future Of Yogurt"]. ''[[Huffington Post]]''. December 17, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.turkofamerica.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1223&Itemid=57 "Chobani Opens World's Largest Yogurt Manufacturing Plant in Twin Falls, Idaho"]. ''[[Turk of America]]''. December 19, 2012.</ref> His pastimes when he is not working include sailing, traveling, and spending time with his two German shepherds.<ref>[http://chobani.co.uk/current/wp-content/themes/chobani/media_kit/Media-Kit-Our-Team.pdf "Hamdi	Ulukaya: Founder, CEO and President"]. Chobani UK Media Kit. 2012.</ref>

title: User talk:76.9.54.69
content: == Welcome to Wikipedia! == Hello, and [[Wikipedia:Introduction|welcome]] to Wikipedia! Thank you for [[Special:Contributions/76.9.54.69|your contributions]]. I hope you like the place and decide to stay. Here are some pages you might like to see: * [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] * [[Help:Contents|Help pages]] * [[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] * [[Wikipedia:How to edit a page|How to edit a page]] and [[Wikipedia:Article development|How to develop articles]] * [[Wikipedia:Simplified Manual of Style|Simplified Manual of Style]] * [[Help:Wikipedia: The Missing Manual/Introduction|Intuitive guide to Wikipedia]] You are welcome to continue editing without [[Special:Userlogin|logging in]], but you may want to consider '''[{{fullurl:Special:Userlogin|type=signup&campaign=anonwelcometemplate}} creating an account]'''. Doing so is free, requires no personal information, and provides several benefits such as the ability to create articles. For a full outline and explanation of the benefits that come with creating an account, please see [[Wikipedia:Why create an account?|this page]]. If you edit without a username, your [[IP address]] (76.9.54.69) is used to identify you instead. In any case, I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Signatures|sign your comments]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your IP address (or username if you're logged in) and the date. If you need help, check out [[Wikipedia:Questions]], ask me on [[User talk:BracketBot|my talk page]], or ask your question and then place {{[[:Category:Wikipedians looking for help|helpme]]}} before the question on this page. Again, welcome! == March 2014 == [[File:Information.svg|25px|alt=|link=]] Hello, I'm [[User:BracketBot|BracketBot]]. I have automatically detected that [//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?diff=598360244 your edit] to [[List of festivals in Canada]] may have broken the [[syntax]] by modifying 2 "[]"s. If you have, don't worry: just [{{fullurl:List of festivals in Canada|action=edit&minor=minor&summary=Fixing+typo+raised+by+%5B%5BUser%3ABracketBot%7CBracketBot%5D%5D}} edit the page] again to fix it. If I misunderstood what happened, or if you have any questions, you can leave a message on [//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?action=edit&preload=User:A930913/BBpreload&editintro=User:A930913/BBeditintro&minor=&title=User_talk:A930913&preloadtitle=BracketBot%20–%20{{subst:REVISIONUSER}}§ion=new my operator's talk page]. :List of unpaired brackets remaining on the page: **{{red|'''[['''}}Dawson City, Yukon Music Festival It's OK to remove this message. Also, to stop receiving these messages, follow [[User:BracketBot#Opting out|these opt-out instructions]]. Thanks, [[User:BracketBot|BracketBot]] ([[User talk:BracketBot|talk]]) 05:40, 6 March 2014 (UTC)

title: Template:Lincolnshire preceptories
content:
<!-- for transcluding into all the relevant pages listed here -->
<onlyinclude>
==Lincolnshire preceptories==
Until their disbandment in 1312, the Knights Templar were major landowners on the higher lands of Lincolnshire, where they had a number of preceptories on property which provided income, while [[Temple Bruer]] was an estate on the Lincoln Heath, believed to have been used also for military training.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ward|first=Penny|title=The Knights Templar in Kesteven|publisher=Heritage Lincolnshire Publications|location=Heckington|isbn=978-0-948639-47-0|edition=2|editor=Dennis Mills (2nd ed.)}}</ref> The preceptories from which the Lincolnshire properties were managed were:<ref>{{cite book|series=Victoria County History|title=A History of the County of Lincoln|volume=2|editor-first=William |editor-last=Page|year=1906|pages = 210-213 'Houses of Knights Templars: Willoughton, Eagle, Aslackby, South Witham and Temple Bruer' |url= http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=38047 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
*[[Aslackby Preceptory]], [[Kesteven]] ({{gbmappingsmall|TF0830}})
*[[Bottesford Preceptory|Bottesford]], [[Lindsey (government district)|Lindsey]] ({{gbmappingsmall|SE8907}})
*[[Eagle, Lincolnshire|Eagle]], Kesteven ({{gbmappingsmall|SK875672}})
*[[Great Limber]], Lindsey ({{gbmappingsmall|TA1308}})
*[[Horkstow]], Lindsey ({{gbmappingsmall|SE9818}})
*[[Witham Preceptory]], Kesteven ({{gbmappingsmall|SK928205}})
*[[Temple Bruer]], Kesteven ({{gbmappingsmall|TF0054}})
*[[Willoughton Preceptory]], Lindsey ({{gbmappingsmall|SK923931}})
*[[Byards Leap|Byard's Leap]] ({{gbmappingsmall|SK990494}}) was part of the Temple Bruer estate.
</onlyinclude>

title: Henri Verbrugghen
content:
'''Henri Verbrugghen''' (1 August 1873{{spaced ndash}}12 November 1934) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] musician, who directed orchestras in [[England]], [[Scotland]], [[Australia]] and the [[United States]].

Born in [[Brussels]], Verbrugghen made his first appearance as a violinist when only eight years old, and was a successful student at the Brussels Conservatorium under [[Jenő Hubay|Hubay]] and [[Eugène Ysaÿe|Ysaye]], winning many prizes. He visited England with Ysaye in 1888, and in 1893 settled in Scotland as a member of the [[Scottish Orchestra]]. During the summer he led the orchestra at [[Llandudno]] under [[Jules Riviere]]. For a time he was a member of the [[Lamoureux Orchestra]] at [[Paris]] and then for three years was deputy-conductor at Llandudno. He was director of music for four years at [[Colwyn Bay]], and then returned to the Scottish Orchestra.

In 1902 he became leader and deputy-conductor under [[Frederic Cowen]], and during the promenade season led the [[Queen's Hall]] Orchestra for three years.

In 1907, he was the soloist in the first performance in England of the [[Violin Concerto (Sibelius)|Violin Concerto in D minor]] by [[Jean Sibelius]].<ref>Grove's Dictionary of Music and Musicians, 5th ed., 1954</ref>

He became chief violin professor at the Athenaeum, [[Glasgow]], and in 1911 succeeded Dr Coward as conductor of the [[Glasgow Choral Union]]. In April 1914 he enhanced his growing reputation when a [[Beethoven]] Festival was held at London, Verbrugghen "conducting throughout the festival with insight and masterly ability" (The Musical Times, 1 June 1914, p. 399). Early in 1915 he was appointed director of the [[Sydney Conservatorium of Music|New South Wales State Conservatorium]] at a salary of £1,250 a year.

Verbrugghen arrived in [[Sydney]] in the same year full of enthusiasm. He had a great admiration for English-speaking people but did not like the methods of their schools of music, and decided that the conservatorium at Sydney should be based on continental models. He got together a remarkably fine orchestra, including the other members of his excellent string quartet who had come with him. For six years Verbrugghen's influence on the musical life of Sydney was of outstanding importance, but the politicians had not realized that it is impossible to carry on work of this nature without financial loss. The orchestra was disbanded in 1921 and Verbrugghen, who had suffered much from worry, went to America for health reasons.

In 1922 he was a guest conductor of the [[Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra]], and had such a brilliant success that he was given the position of permanent conductor. Efforts were made in Australia to persuade him to return without success. In 1928, he was elected a national honorary member of [[Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia Fraternity]], the American fraternity for men in music. In 1931 he collapsed at a rehearsal of his orchestra, and never completely recovered his health. From September 1933 he was chairman of the Department of Music at [[Carleton College]], [[Northfield, Minnesota|Northfield]], [[Minnesota]], and he died in 1934.

There is a Verbrugghen Street in the suburb of [[Melba, Australian Capital Territory|Melba]] in the Australian national capital, [[Canberra]].  All the streets in the suburb are named after significant figures in Australian music. Verbrugghen Hall at the [[Sydney Conservatorium of Music]] in Sydney also commemorates his name.

==References==
{{reflist}}

==Sources==

If you are stuck, and looking for help, please come to the '''[[Wikipedia:New contributors' help page|New contributors' help page]]''', where experienced Wikipedians can answer any queries you have! Or, you can just type '''{{t|helpme}}''' on this page, and someone will show up shortly to answer your questions. Here are a few other good links for newcomers: * [[Wikipedia:Your first article|Your first article]] * [[Wikipedia:BLP|Biographies of living persons]] * [[Wikipedia:How to write a great article|How to write a great article]] * [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]] * [[Help:Contents|Help pages]] * [[Wikipedia:Tutorial|Tutorial]] I hope you enjoy editing here and being a [[Wikipedia:Wikipedians|Wikipedian]]! Please [[Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|sign your name]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your name and the date. If you have any questions, check out [[Wikipedia:Where to ask a question]] or ask me on {{#if:|[[User talk:{{{2}}}{{!}}my talk page]]|my talk page}}. Again, welcome! [[User:Everyone Dies In the End|Everyone Dies In the End]] ([[User talk:Everyone Dies In the End|talk]]) 13:47, 23 February 2010 (UTC) ==[[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|Speedy deletion]] nomination of [[:Sara Sirotek]]== [[Image:Ambox warning_pn.svg|48px|left]] A tag has been placed on [[:Sara Sirotek]] requesting that it be speedily deleted from Wikipedia. This has been done under [[WP:CSD#A7|section A7 of the criteria for speedy deletion]], because the article appears to be about a person or group of people, but it does not indicate how or why the subject is important or significant: that is, why an article about that subject should be included in an encyclopedia. Under the [[WP:CSD#Articles|criteria for speedy deletion]], such articles may be deleted at any time. Please [[Wikipedia:Notability|see the guidelines for what is generally accepted as notable]], as well as our subject-specific [[Wikipedia:Notability (people)|notability guideline for biographies]]. You may also wish to consider using a Wizard to help you create articles - see the [[Wikipedia:Article wizard2.0|Article Wizard]]. If you think that this notice was placed here in error, you may contest the deletion by adding {{tl|hangon}} to '''the top of [[:Sara Sirotek|the page that has been nominated for deletion]]''' (just below the existing speedy deletion or "db" tag), coupled with adding a note on '''[[Talk:Sara Sirotek|the talk page]]''' explaining your position, but be aware that once tagged for ''speedy'' deletion, if the page meets the criterion, it may be deleted without delay. Please do not remove the speedy deletion tag yourself, but don't hesitate to add information to the page that would render it more in conformance with Wikipedia's policies and guidelines. Lastly, please note that if the page does get deleted, you can contact [[:Category:Wikipedia administrators who will provide copies of deleted articles|one of these admins]] to request that they [[Wikipedia:Userfication#Userfication_of_deleted_content|userfy]] the page or have a copy emailed to you. [[User:Everyone Dies In the End|Everyone Dies In the End]] ([[User talk:Everyone Dies In the End|talk]]) 13:47, 23 February 2010 (UTC)

title: Williamsburg Center Historic District
content:
{{Infobox NRHP | name =Williamsburg Center Historic District
  | nrhp_type = hd    | nocat = yes  
  | image = Old Town Hall, Williamsburg MA.jpg
  | caption = Williamsburg Historical Society
  | location= [[Williamsburg, Massachusetts]]
  | lat_degrees = 42
  | lat_minutes = 23
  | lat_seconds = 32
  | lat_direction = N
  | long_degrees = 72
  | long_minutes = 43
  | long_seconds = 49
  | long_direction = W
  | locmapin = Massachusetts
  | area =
  | built =1771
| architect= Multiple
| architecture= Greek Revival, Queen Anne, Shingle Style
 | added = June 22, 1980
 | governing_body = Local
 | refnum=80000506<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2008a}}</ref>
}}
The '''Williamsburg Center Historic District''' is a historic district on [[Massachusetts Route 9]] in [[Williamsburg, Massachusetts]].  It encompasses the traditional center of the town.  Buildings in the district include the Meekins Library, a Classical Revival building designed in 1897 by Putnam and Bayley,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mhc-macris.net/Details.aspx?MhcId=WLM.19|title=MACRIS inventory record for Meekins Library|publisher=Commonwealth of Massachusetts|accessdate=2013-12-16}}</ref> the former Hampshire Hotel building, built c. 1800 (which also was owned by the local chapter of the [[Women's Christian Temperance Union]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mhc-macris.net/Details.aspx?MhcId=WLM.18|title=MACRIS inventory record for Hampshire Hotel|publisher=Commonwealth of Massachusetts|accessdate=2013-12-16}}</ref> the 1841 former town hall (now home to the local historical society museum),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mhc-macris.net/Details.aspx?MhcId=WLM.6|title=MACRIS inventory record for Williamsburg Town Hall|publisher=Commonwealth of Massachusetts|accessdate=2013-12-16}}</ref> and the 1835 Greek Revival First Congregational Church.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mhc-macris.net/Details.aspx?MhcId=WLM.17|title=MACRIS inventory record for First Congregational Church of Williamsburg|publisher=Commonwealth of Massachusetts|accessdate=2013-12-16}}</ref>

The district includes additional buildings dating from 18th century to the 20th century.  It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1980.<ref name=nris/>

==See also==

*[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Hampshire County, Massachusetts]]

(...) "Igual como llama la atención el hecho que tenga Rut un millón. El mismo número que me dieron cuando saqué carné para rendir el Bachillerato. En ese mismo carné dice Serjio con j, como era entonces."{{Source needs translation}}}}</ref>

'''Serjio Roberto Livingstone Pohlhammer''' (26 March 1920 – 11 September 2012), later simply known as '''Sergio Livingstone''', was a [[Chile]]an [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]], who later became a well regarded journalist. He was nicknamed "El Sapo" ("The Toad") for his typical posture in the goal mouth. From 1938–59 he played primarily for [[Club Deportivo Universidad Católica|CD Universidad Católica]] in Santiago. With [[Chilean national football team|Chile]] he took part in seven [[Copa América|South American Championship]]s and one World Cup.

==Career==
Serjio (later Sergio) Livingstone's family hailed from [[Scotland]]. His father John, who played for [[Santiago National|Santiago National FC]], was a pioneer of the game in Chile. Livingstone originally joined [[Unión Española]]. He abandoned football to study law at the [[Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile]]. Soon he acquainted himself with the university's football team, and from 1938 he began to establish himself as the goalkeeper of [[Club Deportivo Universidad Católica|CD Universidad Católica]].
[[File:Sergio Livingstone - Racing - 1943.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Livingstone wearing his Racing Club jersey]]
He debuted in the [[Chilean national football team|national team]] at the [[1941 South American Championship]] which took place in Chile, winning 5–0 against [[Ecuador]]. By the end of the tournament Chile ended third, and Livingstone was considered the best player of the tournament. Altogether, Livingstone played between 1941 and 1954 in 52 matches for Chile,<ref>Roberto Mamrud. [http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/chil-recintlp.html Chilean Record International Players] 19 February 2010, RSSSF</ref> which made him the country's record international until 1962, participating in five more South American Championships, totaling 34 matches in this competition, which remains record. He also took part in the [[FIFA World Cup 1950|World Cup 1950]] in Brazil, where Chile exited after the first group phase. {{Citation needed|date=September 2012}}

At club level he spent 1943 in Argentina playing 30 matches for [[Racing Club de Avellaneda|Racing Club]]. He cut short his time in [[Argentina]] for sentimental reasons and rejoined Católica in 1944, winning the national championships of 1949 and 1954. After the second title the club had the misfortune to be relegated in the season immediately thereafter, but managed to return to the first division as quickly. After a brief spell on loan in 1957 with [[CSD Colo-Colo]] he once more returned to Católica where he finished his career in 1959.
Following his football career, he became a well-known sports journalist and television personality with [[Televisión Nacional de Chile|TVN]], where he remained until his death(more than 60 years).  {{Citation needed|date=September 2012}}

==Legacy==
In 2009, a [http://www.lanacion.cl/prontus_noticias_v2/site/artic/20090416/pags/20090416220023.html street] in the district of [[Independencia, Chile|Independencia]] in Santiago was named for Livingstone.

==Titles==
*[[Primera División de Chile|National Championship]]: 1949, 1954 for the Universidad Católica

'''Why can't I edit Wikipedia?'''

[[Special:MyContributions|Your account's edits]] and/or username indicate that it is being used on behalf of a company, group, celebrity or other well-known individual, or organization for purposes of promotion and/or publicity. The edits may have violated one or more of our rules on spamming, which include: [[WP:LINKSPAM|adding inappropriate external links]], [[WP:Spam|posting advertisements]], and [[WP:PROMOTION|using Wikipedia for promotion]]. Also, review the [[WP:Conflict of interest|conflict of interest guidance]] to see the kinds of limitations you would have to obey if you did want to continue editing about your company, group, organization, or clients. title: Talk:Oriental Powder Company
Cathiravelu Ponnambalam
content:
'''C. Ponnambalam''' (Cathiravelu Ponnambalam) was the First [[Mayor]] of Jaffna.<ref name="ts1">{{cite web | url= http://www.dailynews.lk/2004/02/26/new18.html| title=Stamp to honour Cathiravelu Sittampalam| date= 2004-02-26 | publisher= The Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Ltd [Daily News]|accessdate=2008-03-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url= http://sundaytimes.lk/070923/FunDay/heritage.html| title=First cabinet had only 14 ministers| date= 2007-09-23 | publisher= Wijeya Newspapers Ltd, Sri Lanka[The Sunday Times]|accessdate=2008-03-01}}</ref>

==Biography==
Ponnambalam hailed from a distinguished Tamil family from [[Jaffna]]. His father Arumugam Cathiravelu was a Magistrate and District Judge. His own brother [[Cathiravelu Sittampalam]] was the first [[Cabinet Minister]] of [[Mail|Posts]] and [[Telecommunications]] in the independent [[Sri Lanka]]. His uncle [[Arumugam Canagaratnam]] was the Chairman of the first Urban Council of Jaffna and built and founded [[Canagaratnam Maha Vidyalayam]]. Ponnambalam's grand uncle [[Viswanather Casipillai]] was a [[The Crown|Crown]] [[Proctor]] and co-founder of the [[Jaffna Hindu College]]. His brother-in-law C. Casipillai was the Third Mayor of Jaffna.<ref name="ts1"/>

== See also ==
*[[List of political families in Sri Lanka]]

title: The Tenth Planet
content:
{{About|the Doctor Who serial|the hypothetical planet beyond Neptune|Planets beyond Neptune|other subjects related to "tenth planet"|Tenth planet (disambiguation)}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox Doctor Who episode| |number=029 |image=[[File:Tenth Planet.jpg|250px]] |caption=The Cybermen take over the Snowcap base from General Cutler |serial_name= The Tenth Planet |show=DW |type=serial |doctor=[[William Hartnell]] ([[First Doctor]]) *[[Patrick Troughton]] ([[Second Doctor]]) (uncredited) |companion=[[Anneke Wills]] ([[Polly (Doctor Who)|Polly]]) |companion2=[[Michael Craze]] ([[Ben Jackson (Doctor Who)|Ben Jackson]]) |guests= *[[Robert Beatty]] — General Cutler *David Dodimead — Barclay *Dudley Jones — Dyson *Alan White — Schultz *[[Earl Cameron (actor)|Earl Cameron]] — Williams *Callen Angelo — Terry Cutler *[[John Brandon (actor)|John Brandon]] — American Sergeant *Shane Shelton — Tito *[[Steve Plytas]] — Wigner *Christopher Matthews — Radar Technician *Ellen Cullen — Geneva Technician *Christopher Dunham — R/T Technician *Glenn Beck — TV Announcer *[[Roy Skelton]], [[Peter Hawkins]] — Cybermen Voices *Harry Brooks, Reg Whitehead, Gregg Palmer — Cybermen |writer=[[Kit Pedler]]
[[Gerry Davis (screenwriter)|Gerry Davis]] (episodes 3, 4) |director=[[Derek Martinus]] |script_editor=Gerry Davis |producer=[[Innes Lloyd]] |composer=[[Stock music]] |production_code=DD |series=[[Doctor Who (season 4)|Season 4]] |length=4 episodes, 25 minutes each |missing_eps=1 episode (4) |started=8 October 1966 |ended=29 October 1966 |preceding=''[[The Smugglers]]'' |following=''[[The Power of the Daleks]]'' |}} '''''The Tenth Planet''''' is the [[Doctor Who missing episodes|partly missing]] second [[list of Doctor Who serials|serial]] of the fourth season in the British [[science fiction on television|science fiction television]] series ''[[Doctor Who]]'', which was first broadcast in four weekly parts from 8 to 29 October 1966. It was [[William Hartnell]]'s last regular appearance as the [[First Doctor]], and the first story to feature the [[Cyberman|Cybermen]]. [[Patrick Troughton]] also makes his first, uncredited appearance as the [[Second Doctor]]. Only three of the four episodes are held in the BBC archives; one [[Doctor Who missing episodes|remains missing]] although the regeneration sequence and various other scenes have been discovered intact. It is the fourth [[List of incomplete Doctor Who serials|now-incomplete Doctor Who serial]] to be released with a full-length [[Animation|animated]] reconstruction of its [[Doctor Who missing episodes|missing episode]].{{cite web|title=Tenth Planet Animation|url=http://www.doctorwho.tv/whats-new/images/the-tenth-planet-animation/|work=BBC Doctor Who Website|accessdate=2 September 2013}} ==Plot== {{Plot|date=October 2015}} [[Doctor (Doctor Who)|The Doctor]] and his companions [[Ben Jackson (Doctor Who)|Ben]] and [[Polly (Doctor Who)|Polly]] arrive in the [[TARDIS]] at the [[South Pole]] in the year 1986, near the Snowcap base. The base is supervising the mission of the ''Zeus IV'' spaceship, running a routine probe on the [[Earth]]'s atmosphere. Unusual readings on the spaceship's instruments lead to the discovery of a new planet suddenly approaching Earth. The spaceship begins to experience power losses, and Snowcap personnel begin arrangements to abort its mission. Back on the base, the Doctor reveals what he knows about the [[tenth planet]]: it is [[Mondas]], Earth's former sister planet and its inhabitants will soon be visiting Earth. True to his prediction, three robotic creatures land outside, killing the guards and disguising themselves in the dead men's furs to gain access. While everyone is distracted by their efforts to land ''Zeus IV'' safely, the creatures are easily able to take over the base. The base personnel and Polly plead with the invaders to allow them to save the lives of the ''Zeus IV'' crew, but the creatures say that their lives are irrelevant to them. They explain that they are [[Cyberman|Cybermen]], who were once like human beings, but gradually replaced their bodies with mechanical parts, including eliminating the "weakness" of [[emotion]] from their [[brain]]s. The Cybermen allow the men to make contact with ''Zeus IV'', but it is too late as the ship is dragged away by Mondas and explodes. The Cybermen explain that Mondas is absorbing energy from Earth and will soon destroy it. They propose to take humans back to Mondas and turn them into Cybermen. Ben, who has been imprisoned in the projection room after attempting to kill a Cyberman, rigs up the projector to blind incoming Cybermen, allowing him to steal his guard's weapon and kill him. Sneaking back into the Tracking Room, he hands the cyberweapon to General Cutler, the base commander, who kills the remaining two Cybermen. Cutler contacts Space Command HQ in [[Geneva]] and is informed that they have sent his son on a mission to rescue the doomed ''Zeus IV''. Cutler decides it is time to take the fight to the Cybermen and decides to use the powerful Z-bomb to destroy Mondas. Ben argues against using the bomb, saying that Mondas might destroy itself anyway when it absorbs too much energy. The chief scientist at Snowcap, Dr. Barclay, is also concerned, saying that the [[radioactive contamination|radiation]] caused by the exploding planet would cause great loss of life on Earth. Unswayed, Cutler orders Ben to be imprisoned in a cabin with the Doctor, who is unconscious and seemingly ill. Barclay goes to Ben and tells him how to sabotage the rocket to prevent it from reaching Mondas, but Cutler notices Barclay's absence and catches Ben in the act. Cutler attempts to fire the Z-bomb, but the engines fail on the launchpad thanks to Ben's sabotage. Cutler, enraged, threatens to kill Ben, Barclay, and the Doctor, who has now regained consciousness. Before he can shoot the Doctor, Cutler is killed by the leader of a newly arrived squad of Cybermen. The Cybermen insist that the rocket pointed at Mondas be dismantled. The Doctor suggests that it would be a good idea to go along with this, and tells the others to play for time, as Mondas cannot take much more energy now. The Cybermen take Polly back to their spaceship as a hostage. As the Cybermen take over Space Command in Geneva, the Doctor realises that their plan is to destroy the Earth with the Z-bombs, thus saving Mondas. He manages to communicate this revelation to Ben and the others over the intercom before the Cybermen take him prisoner. In the radiation room, Ben surmises that the reason why they need to use humans to do this work rather than doing it themselves is that they are highly susceptible to radiation. Barclay suggests using the rods from the reactor chamber as a portable weapon against the Cybermen. This proves successful, allowing Ben, Barclay, and the others to regain control of the base. More Cybermen enter the Tracking Room, but just at that moment Mondas explodes, disabling all the remaining Cybermen. [[File:Tenth Planet 2.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The Doctor regenerates for the first time.]] Cutler's son contacts the base from ''Zeus IV'', telling them that his ship is now back to full power and Geneva tells Barclay that the Cyberman threat has ended. Meanwhile, Ben makes his way back to the Cybermen's ship to rescue the Doctor and Polly. The Doctor seems to deliberate as to whether "it's all over" before settling that it's "far from over" before making his way back to the TARDIS. As Ben and Polly hammer on the door, the controls operate of their own accord and the central column begins to rise and fall. The Doctor seizes enough energy to open the door and Ben and Polly finally get in. Barely conscious, the Doctor collapses to the floor, and before the astonished eyes of his companions, he becomes enveloped in a bright light. After the light dies down, the Doctor`s face is different and has the appearance of a [[Second Doctor|younger man]]. ===Continuity=== The events leading up to this story, from the Cybermen's perspective, are heard in the [[Big Finish Productions|Big Finish]] audio story ''[[Spare Parts (Doctor Who)|Spare Parts]]'' with the [[Fifth Doctor]] and [[Nyssa (Doctor Who)|Nyssa]]. The story deals with many aspects left unexplained in this story; such as how Mondas left the solar system and returned again. The [[Sixth Doctor]] serial, ''[[Attack of the Cybermen]]'', takes place in 1985, a year before the events of ''The Tenth Planet''. In that serial the Cybermen attempt to alter history so Mondas is not destroyed. While the Doctor [[Regeneration (Doctor Who)|regenerates]] at the end of this story, the process is unnamed. In the subsequent serial, ''[[The Power of the Daleks]]'', the Doctor states that he has been "renewed", implying a restoration of youth rather than a change of body. The concept was not called "regeneration" until ''[[Planet of the Spiders]]''. Script editor Gerry Davis later stated that it was intended for the energy drain from Mondas to be the cause of the regeneration, but that it did not come across clearly on screen. ==Production== All four episodes of this story feature a specially designed graphics sequence used for the opening titles and closing credits. Designed by Bernard Lodge, they were intended to resemble a computer printout.http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/episodeguide/tenthplanet/detail.shtml In the opening credits for the first episode, Kit Pedler is incorrectly identified as "Kitt Pedler". In the opening credits for the third episode, Gerry Davis is incorrectly identified as "Gerry Davies." William Hartnell did not appear in the third episode.http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/episodeguide/tenthplanet/detail.shtml On the Monday before the programme was due to be recorded, he sent a telegram to the production team informing them that he was too ill to work. Gerry Davis rewrote the script to explain the Doctor's absence (his sudden collapse) and gave his dialogue to other characters, most noticeably Ben. This was not as much of an interruption to the episode's production as it would seem, as all four episodes had been written so that Hartnell would have relatively little to do in case of just such an event. The original draft of episode 4 did not feature the Doctor regenerating at the end.{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorwhonews.net/2013/09/original-tenth-planet-script-found.html |title=Original Tenth Planet Script Found |publisher=Doctor Who News |date=2013-01-09 |accessdate=2013-10-09}} The First Doctor's last words were originally scripted as something similar to "No... no, I simply will not give in!" Time was running short towards the end of production, and director [[Derek Martinus]] opted not to record the line, wanting to ensure that the regeneration sequence was recorded as well as possible. As a result, the First Doctor's last words were simply "Ah! Yes. Thank you. That's good, keep warm." ===Cast notes=== Patrick Troughton appears in the final episode, uncredited, as the Second Doctor. William Hartnell would reprise the role of the First Doctor on only one occasion: the tenth anniversary serial ''[[The Three Doctors (Doctor Who)|The Three Doctors]]'', although a photograph of him would be seen briefly as Troughton first looks into a mirror at the start of Troughton's first serial, ''[[The Power of the Daleks]]''; the first episode begins with a shot of Troughton lying on the TARDIS floor. A clip of Hartnell from part 6 of ''[[The Dalek Invasion of Earth]]'' was used at the beginning of the 20th anniversary special, ''[[The Five Doctors]]'' (where [[Richard Hurndall]] would play the First Doctor during most of the episode). A clip of Hartnell from ''The Tenth Planet'' was used in ''[[Earthshock]]'', when the Cybermen review the Doctor's change of appearance. ===Missing episode=== The last episode of this serial is [[Doctor Who missing episodes|missing]]. It is possibly the most sought-after of the missing episodes, because it contains the historic first regeneration scene (even though a low-quality, truncated copy of this sequence survives and is held in the BBC Archives), and also because it is William Hartnell's final episode. In fact, it is included in a list of the ten most wanted missing programmes{{citation needed|reason=Where is a list of 10 most wanted missing programmes?|date=June 2015}} alongside the BBC studio footage from the [[Apollo 11]] landings (which is currently held only in soundtrack form). Popular myth has it that the only surviving [[telerecording]] copy of the fourth episode was lost when loaned out to the children's programme ''[[Blue Peter]]'' in 1973 when they wished to use a clip from it in a feature on the tenth anniversary of ''Doctor Who''.http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/episodeguide/tenthplanet/detail.shtml Although a print of ''[[The Daleks' Master Plan]]'' Episode 4 ("The Traitors") was loaned to ''Blue Peter'' and not returned to the BBC Film Library, there was never a copy of ''The Tenth Planet'' Episode 4 there to have been loaned. Another department – [[BBC Worldwide|BBC Enterprises]] – was still offering all four episodes for sale to foreign broadcasters until the end of the following year and would not, in any case, have loaned out master negatives. In 1992, a man named Roger K. Barrett (later revealed to be an alias; it being based on the real name of [[Syd Barrett]]) claimed to have a videotape recording of Episode 4 of this story, and offered to sell it to the BBC for £500. Before this was revealed as a hoax, the BBC produced a special introduction for an intended VHS release of the story, hosted by [[Michael Craze]], two versions of which were filmed: one explaining that Episode 4 was still missing, the other introducing the story as if it were complete. A documentary called "Missing in Action", made in 1993 and narrated by Nicholas Courtney, also mentions the hoax. For the 2013 DVD release, episode four was animated by Planet 55 Studios.http://planet55studios.com.au/doctor-who-the-tenth-planet/ ==Broadcast and reception== {{Doctor Who episode head |Archive=Y | {{Doctor Who episode body|Episode 1|{{Start date|1966|10|8|df=y}}|23:08|5.5|16mm t/r|Archive=y}} {{Doctor Who episode body|Episode 2|{{Start date|1966|10|15|df=y}}|23:15|6.4|16mm t/r|Archive=y}} {{Doctor Who episode body|Episode 3|{{Start date|1966|10|22|df=y}}|23:31|7.6|16mm t/r|Archive=y}} {{Doctor Who episode body|Episode 4|{{Start date|1966|10|29|df=y}}|24:02|7.5|Archive=y|Fragment=y}} | {{cite web |url= http://gallifreyone.com/episode.php?id=dd |title= The Tenth Planet |publisher = Outpost Gallifrey |author = Shaun Lyon|date = 2007-03-31 |accessdate = 2008-08-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080331033327/http://www.gallifreyone.com/episode.php?id=dd |archivedate = 2008-03-31|display-authors=etal}} {{cite web |url= http://www.drwhoguide.com/who_2d.htm |title= The Tenth Planet |publisher = Doctor Who Reference Guide |date = |accessdate = 2008-08-30 }} {{cite web |url= http://www.shannonsullivan.com/drwho/serials/dd.html |title= The Tenth Planet |publisher = A Brief History of Time Travel |last = Sullivan |first = Shannon |date = 2006-05-10 |accessdate = 2008-08-30 }} }} In 2009, Patrick Mulkern of ''[[Radio Times]]'' found the original Cybermen design like "usherettes from some kinky, futuristic moviehouse", but praised the character of Cutler and Hartnell's Doctor.{{cite web|first=Patrick|last=Mulkern|url= http://www.radiotimes.com/blog/2009-04-14/doctor-who-the-tenth-planet|title=Doctor Who: The Tenth Planet|work=[[Radio Times]]|date=14 April 2009|accessdate=9 February 2013}} Den of Geek named the cliffhanger of Episode 4 as one of the programme's ten "classic" cliffhangers.{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.us/tv/doctor-who/20847/10-classic-doctor-who-cliffhangers|title=10 classic Doctor Who cliffhangers|publisher=Den of Geek|date=2 June 2011|accessdate=9 February 2013}} Alasdair Wilkins of [[io9]] described it as "a very solid, at times excellent story" and noted "The Cybermen have possibly been more intimidating in other stories, but they have never been creepier than they are here". He named it the fourth best regeneration and regeneration story.{{cite web|first=Alasdair|last=Wilkins|url=http://io9.com/5437510/ranking-the-regenerations-of-doctor-who|title=Ranking The Regnerations Of Doctor Who|publisher=[[io9]]|date=1 January 2010|accessdate=16 March 2013}} [[DVD Talk]]'s John Sinnott gave the story four and a half out of five stars. He praised Hartnell's performance and the Cybermen.{{cite web|first=John|last=Sinnott|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/62123/doctor-who-the-tenth-planet/|title=Doctor Who: The Tenth Planet|publisher=[[DVD Talk]]|date=22 November 2013|accessdate=30 November 2013}} Ian Berriman of ''[[SFX (magazine)|SFX]]'' was more mixed, giving the serial three out of five stars. He praised the Cybermen and the "palpable tension", but felt that the regeneration was tacked on and not enough background was given to make Mondas believable.{{cite web|first=Ian|last=Berriman|url=http://www.sfx.co.uk/2013/10/17/doctor-who-the-tenth-planet-review/|title=Doctor Who: The Tenth Planet Review|work=[[SFX (magazine)|SFX]]|date=17 October 2013|accessdate=19 October 2013}} ==Commercial releases== ===In print=== {{Infobox book |name = Doctor Who and the Tenth Planet |image = Doctor Who and the Tenth Planet.jpg |border = yes |caption = |author = [[Gerry Davis (screenwriter)|Gerry Davis]] |cover_artist = [[Chris Achilleos]] |series = ''[[Doctor Who]]'' book:
[[List of Doctor Who novelisations|Target novelisations]] |release_number = 62 |release_date = 19 February 1976 |publisher = [[Target Books]] |pages = |isbn= 0-426-11068-4 |preceded_by = |followed_by = }} A novelisation of this serial, written by [[Gerry Davis (screenwriter)|Gerry Davis]], was published by [[Target Books]] in February 1976. It was the first Hartnell-era serial novelisation to be commissioned by Target, and the first new adaptation of a Hartnell adventure to be published in nearly ten years. The novelisation largely follows the original script and so places the action in the year 2000 as well as restoring the Doctor to the third episode. Also, in the first scene in which the Doctor, Ben and Polly appear (in the TARDIS), the Doctor is beginning to show signs of his failing health; sometimes mistakenly addressing Ben and Polly as "[[Ian Chesterton|Ian]]" and "[[Barbara Wright (Doctor Who)|Barbara]]", thereby revealing signs that all is not as it should be. Also, the regeneration of the Doctor occurs in the TARDIS differently. The Doctor uses what appears to be a rejuvenation chamber that assists him in his regeneration. ===Home media=== The story was released on [[VHS]] in the UK in 2000 from BBC Video, with the fourth episode reconstructed by the [[Doctor Who Restoration Team]] using still photos, existing clips and the surviving audio soundtrack. This release was a double-tape set entitled "Doctor Who: The Cybermen Box Set: The Tenth Planet and [[Attack of the Cybermen]]". In the U.S. and Canada both stories were released individually in 2001. The existing clips from the missing final episode – 8 mm film recordings made by fans and a 16mm film clip of the regeneration (from a 1973 edition of Blue Peter) – were included in the [[DVD]] release ''[[Lost in Time (Doctor Who)|Lost in Time]]'' in 2004. The only surviving clip of the regeneration was also released as a special feature on the DVD releases for ''[[The Three Doctors (Doctor Who)|The Three Doctors]]'' and ''[[Castrovalva (Doctor Who)|Castrovalva]]''. The story was released on DVD on 14 October 2013,{{cite web |url=http://www.bbcshop.com/doctor-who/doctor-who-the-tenth-planet-dvd/invt/bbcdvd3382 |title=Doctor Who: The Tenth Planet (DVD) |accessdate=15 October 2013 }} with the missing fourth episode animated{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorwho.tv/whats-new/article/classic-doctor-who-to-be-animated-for-dvd-release|accessdate=22 August 2013|title=CLASSIC DOCTOR WHO TO BE ANIMATED FOR DVD RELEASE|publisher=http://www.doctorwho.tv}}{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorwhonews.net/2013/02/australian-fans-preview-animated-tenth.html|accessdate=22 August 2013|title=australian fans preview animated the tenth planet|publisher=http://www.doctorwhonews.net/}} along with additional extra features including the original reconstruction of episode four from the 2000 VHS Release included as an extra and a special "Frozen Out" documentary on the making of the story. The "Regenerations" box set, released on 24 June 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00BWU1ESO/ref=ox_sc_sfl_title_4?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=A3P5ROKL5A1OLE|title=Regenerations|publisher=http://www.amazon.co.uk/}} contains ''The Tenth Planet'' (including the newly animated fourth episode). The serial was released with no special features. {{citation needed|date=April 2013|reason=Amazon gives only set title and release date - nothing about content, let alone extras or state of restoration}} The soundtracks for ''The Tenth Planet'' and ''[[The Invasion (Doctor Who)|The Invasion]]'', put together from fan-made recordings, along with a bonus disc, ''The Origins of the Cybermen'', an audio essay by Cyberman actor [[David Banks (actor)|David Banks]], were released on CD in a collector's tin called ''Doctor Who: Cybermen''. ===Music release=== {{Infobox album | Name = Dr Who - Music from the Tenth Planet | Type = Soundtrack | Artist = | Cover = Music from the 10th planet.jpg | Released = 2000 | Recorded = | Genre = Soundtrack | Length = 19:01 | Label = Ochre Records | Producer = | Reviews = | Chronology = [[Doctor Who Soundtrack|''Doctor Who'' soundtrack]] | Last album = ''[[Doctor Who at the BBC Radiophonic Workshop Volume 2: New Beginnings 1970–1980]]''
(2000) | This album = ''Dr Who - Music from the Tenth Planet''
(2000) | Next album = ''[[Doctor Who at the BBC Radiophonic Workshop Volume 3: The Leisure Hive]]''
(2002) }} A CD of stock music used in this serial was released in 2000.{{cite AV media notes |title = Dr Who - Music from the Tenth Planet |year = 2000 |type = CD Booklet |publisher = Ochre Records |id= OCH050 |location = [[Cheltenham]], United Kingdom}} ====Track listing==== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Track # ! Composer ! Track name |- |1 |[[Roger Roger (composer)|Roger Roger]] |"Blast Off!" |- |2 |Walter Stott |"Music for Technology" |- |3 |[[Douglas Gamley]] |"Power Drill" |- |4 |rowspan=3|[[Martin Slavin]] |"Space Adventure Part 1" |- |5 |"Space Adventure Part 2" |- |6 |"Space Adventure Part 3" |- |7 |rowspan=2|Dennis Farnon |"Drama in Miniature Part 1" |- |8 |"Drama in Miniature Part 2" |- |9 |Douglas Gamley |"Machine Room" |- |10 |rowspan=2|[[Robert Farnon]] |"Drumdramatics 7" |- |11 |"Drumdramatics 10" |} {{see also|Music from The Tomb of the Cybermen|Space Adventures - Music from 'Doctor Who' 1963–1968}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|First Doctor}} *{{BBCCDW|id=tenthplanet|title=The Tenth Planet}} *{{Brief |id=dd | title=The Tenth Planet}} *{{Doctor Who RG | id=who_2d | title=The Tenth Planet}} ===Reviews=== *{{OG review | id=dd | title=The Tenth Planet}} *{{DWRG | id=tent | title=The Tenth Planet}} ===Target novelisation=== *{{DWRG | id=tentnov | title=Doctor Who and the Tenth Planet}} *[http://www.personal.leeds.ac.uk/~ecl6nb/OnTarget/1976/tenth/76tenth.htm On Target — ''Doctor Who and the Tenth Planet''] {{Doctor Who episodes|C4}} {{First Doctor stories}} {{Doctor Who missing episodes}} {{Regeneration stories}} {{Cybermen stories}} {{Doctor Who soundtracks |state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tenth Planet, The}} [[Category:First Doctor serials]] [[Category:Doctor Who missing episodes]] [[Category:Cybermen television stories]] [[Category:1966 television episodes]] [[Category:1986 in fiction]] [[Category:Television episodes set in Antarctica]] [[Category:Doctor Who stories set on Earth]] [[Category:Second Doctor serials]]

title: Pavement (architecture)
content:
{{Other uses|Pavement (disambiguation)}}

'''Pavement''' in [[construction]] is an outdoor floor or superficial surface covering. Paving materials include [[Asphalt concrete|asphalt]], [[concrete]], stone such as [[flagstone]], [[cobblestone]], and [[Sett (paving)|setts]], [[artificial stone]], [[brick]]s, [[tile]]s, and sometimes wood. In [[landscape architecture]] pavements are part of the [[hardscape]] and are used on [[sidewalk]]s, [[road surface]]s, [[patio]]s, [[courtyard]]s, etc.

''Pavement'' comes from Latin ''pavimentum'' meaning a floor beaten or rammed down, through Old French ''pavement''.<ref>[http://triggs.djvu.org/century-dictionary.com/djvu2jpgframes.php?volno=05&page=779&query=pavement "Pavement", ''The Century Dictionary'']</ref> The meaning of a beaten down floor was obsolete before the word became English.<ref>"pavement, n." ''Oxford English Dictionary'' Second Edition on CD-ROM (v. 4.0) © Oxford University Press 2009</ref>

Pavement laid in patterns such as [[mosaics]] were commonly used by the Romans.

==Paver==
[[Image:Paver Blocks Exterior Circular 3008px.jpg|thumb|right|Concrete paver blocks laid in a circular pattern]]
[[Image:PaverPatio.jpg|thumb|right|Concrete paver blocks in a rectangular pattern]]
A '''paver''' is a paving stone, tile,<ref>"paver" def. 2. ''Oxford English Dictionary'' Second Edition on CD-ROM (v. 4.0) © Oxford University Press 2009</ref> brick<ref>[http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/paving%20brick "Paving brick". The Free Dictionary.com] accessed May 1, 2014</ref> or brick-like piece of concrete commonly used as exterior [[floor]]ing. In a factory, concrete pavers are made by pouring a mixture of concrete and some type of coloring agent into a mold of some shape and allowing to set. They are applied by pouring a standard concrete foundation, spreading sand on top, and then laying the pavers in the desired pattern. No actual [[adhesive]] or retaining method is used other than the weight of the paver itself except edging. Pavers can be used to make roads, driveways, patios, walkways and other outdoor platforms.

===Interlocking concrete pavers===
[[File:Paving stone driveway.jpg|thumb|Interlocking Concrete Paver Driveway]]
An '''interlocking concrete paver''' is a type of paver.  This special type of paver, also known as a '''segmental paver''', has emerged over the last couple of decades in the [[United States]] as a very popular alternative to [[brick]], [[clay]] or [[concrete]].<ref name="ICPI">http://www.icpi.org/theindustry</ref>

Segmental pavers have been used for thousands of years.  The [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] built roads with them<ref name="Pacific paving stone">http://www.pacificpavingstone.com/use-of-paving-stones/</ref> that are still there.  But it was not until the mid-1940s that pavers began to be produced out of concrete.  It started in the [[Netherlands]]<ref name="ICPI" /><ref name="Pacific paving stone" /> where all the roads are made to be flexible because the country is below sea level and the ground shifts, moves and sinks. Poured [[concrete]] is not an option because it will crack.  Individual units not set in concrete, and placed in [[sand]] perform far better than concrete.<ref name="ICPI" />  Before the paver was made from concrete either real [[stone]] or a clay product were used.

The first concrete pavers were shaped just like a brick, 4” by 8” (10 cm x 20 cm) and they were called Holland Stones and still are today.  These units turned out to be economical to produce and were exceedingly strong.

==See also==
*[[Macadam]]

Permeable paving
<gallery mode=packed>
File:Roman Road Surface at Herculaneum.jpg|Roman stone pavement in [[Herculaneum]]
File:Ancient road surface.jpg|[[Cobblestone]] pavement in Italy
File:Traces la Bastille.jpg|[[Sett (paving)|Sett]] pavement in Paris
File:Rasenpflasterstein 1.jpg|[[Permeable paving|Permeable pavement]]

File:Siena z03.JPG|Brick pavement in Piazza del Campo, Siena
File:Wooden paving.jpg|Wood paving may be used indoors as a flooring material
</gallery>
